Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Fundamental Physics of The Invisible and The Very Early Universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER grant supports the research of Professor Justin Khoury at the University of Pennsylvania.

As is now increasingly well understood, the energy density of the universe is dominated by contributions from a so-called "dark sector". As part of his research, Professor Khoury will explore the tantalizing prospect that the dark sector includes new light degrees of freedom that mediate long-range forces on cosmological scales, affecting both dark and baryonic matter. To ensure consistency with laboratory and solar system tests of gravity, some screening mechanism is necessary to "hide" these degrees of freedom locally. Professor Khoury therefore aims to probe the theoretical underpinnings of this idea, and fully develop the observational implications of existing screening theories. He also aims to devise novel screening mechanisms within the framework of consistent effective field theories. Professor Khoury will also study a new cosmological framework which he recently developed which might eliminate the need for an early inflationary period of cosmological evolution. This framework, which he calls the "pseudo-conformal universe", provides alternate solutions for many of the classic problems that are also solved by inflation.

Professor Khoury's activities are also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. Professor Khoury will design a freshman seminar for non-science majors, with invited guest lecturers from a new public lecture series hosted jointly by the Center for Particle Cosmology, Penn's Women Studies, and Penn Women's Center. The lecture series will contribute to broader representation of women in science by featuring leading women physicists. Professor Khoury will also build on the series of regular joint workshops he has helped established with Columbia, NYU, and Princeton in order to develop multi-institutional collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dark matter and dark energy are two pillars of the standard model of cosmology, making up 95% of the total energy density of the universe. Despite the overwhelming evidence for their existence, their underlying fundamental physics remain unknown. In the standard model, dark matter is assumed to be comprised of weakly-interacting sub-atomic particles, while dark energy is a cosmological constant. This provides an good fit to observations on the largest scales, from the expansion history to the cosmic microwave background spectrum to the rate of growth of the large scale structure.

 

A key research outcome of the CAREER Award was the development of novel theories of dark matter and dark energy that include new particles and/or forces. In particular, the PI developed a new theory of dark matter based on the rich and well-studied physics of superfluidity. This is motivated by a number of puzzles on the scales of galaxies that have emerged in recent years. These puzzles, together with the persistent failure of increasingly sensitive experiments to detect the elusive dark matter particle, offer a compelling case that the physics of dark matter may be richer than hitherto anticipated. The PI proposed that dark matter forms a superfluid in the central regions of galaxies. The sound waves associated with the superfluid interact with stars and gas in the galaxy and affect their orbital motion. This results in a modified gravitational force law mimicking Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND), an empirical framework that does exquisitely well at explaining the observed properties of galaxies.

 

The tiny temperature anisotropies observed in the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) are tracers of inhomogeneities in the matter distribution from a time when the universe was 400,000 years old. Through gravitational attraction, these primordial density inhomogeneities subsequently grew to form galaxies, clusters of galaxies, and the large scale structure we observe today. The anisotropies are strikingly simple: they are nearly gaussian (their statistics are fully captured by the two-point correlation function) and nearly scale invariant (their statistics are the same on all scales). One of the key questions in cosmology is to understand the origin of these inhomogeneities. In the standard cosmological model the culprit is believed to be inflation --- a burst of exponential expansion shortly after the big bang.

 

Instead of specializing to specific models, the PI’s research focused on the broader question of identifying the symmetries underlying inflation, and determining the observational consequences of those symmetries. A key research outcome of the CAREER Award was the discovery that, remarkably, single-field inflation is governed by infinitely-many global symmetries. The PI and collaborators showed that these symmetries in turn constrain the form of correlation functions through an infinite number of soft-limit theorems or consistency relations. These relations offer model-independent tests for the inflationary paradigm. More generally, these consistency relations are the cosmological analogue of the celebrated soft-pion theorems of the strong interactions developed in the 1960's. Just like the soft-pion theorems, they showed that the consistency relations in cosmology are a consequence of the symmetries underlying inflation. 

 

On the outreach front, the CAREER Award supported a series of public lectures, with the goal of contributing to broader representation of women in STEM fields by featuring leading women physicists. In particular, the PI spearheaded the Annual Women in Physics lecture series at Penn, hosted by the Physics department and the Women in Physics undergraduate group. The first and second annual Women in Physics public lectures (2015 and 2016) were delivered respectively by Prof. Mildred Dresselhaus, the Institute Professor in Physics and Electrical Engineering at MIT, and Prof. Alessandra Buonanno (Max Planck), director of the Astrophysical and Cosmological Relativity department of the Max Planck Institute and a lead theorists in the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) collaboration. The most recent public lecture (2017) was delivered by Dr. Jill Tarter, Bernard Oliver Chair for Search for Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence (SETI) Institute. Among the public, she is perhaps best known for having inspired the character played by Jodie Foster in the movie Contact. All events was sponsored in part by this CAREER Award. The PI was successful in leveraging the NSF’s support to obtain additional internal support, in the form of grants from the Fund to Encourage Women of the Trustees' Council of Penn Women. The lectures were a resounding success, attracting packed rooms of ~150 attendees. The lecturers' visits revolved entirely around undergraduates. It included breakfast and dinner with our Women in Physics group, lunch with the Society of Physics students, and research presentations by some of our physics majors.
